ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 1 hour
1 hr

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Good
good

This course was perfunctory and did not really shed new light on any issues of ethics or social responsibility in the context of academic work for me. There was a sense that the students were required to be there, and so showed up but did not participate. Maybe other years are more engaged, but certainly this class was fairly checked out throughout the semester. Unfortunately, this tends to be a self-reinforcing pattern... a few people check out, more people check out, everyone checks out...
Very useful
good course
Good, the time is a little bit embarrassing though.
The course workload was not much. But it is very helpful!

This course provides important knowledge in research ethics and many other aspects, containing necessary information for almost every graduate student. The lectures are interesting, and would be better if more students can get involved and be motivated to participate in the activities/discussions.
This was a good overview of ethics, applied specifically to public health.
This course is extremely helpful for junior PhD students, it honestly show us the incoming difficulties we may encounter later and provides us practical suggestions

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Cute and knowledgeable.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  good
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Dr. Tschudi is an excellent professor.

Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Dr. Tschudi is thoughtful, engaging, and approachable. I certainly would feel comfortable going to him if any of the issues we talked about come up during my time at Yale.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Great professor, very sensitive to student needs. Very useful advice based on experience
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  very dedicated teacher
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Good instructor

Instructor: Christian Tschudi  I think that Dr. Tschudi does an excellent job at conveying to the students what we REALLY need to know. He cuts through the muck and presents the essentials of ethics in a clear and concise manner.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Great instructor!

Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Dr. Tschudi gives the lectures in an interesting and easy-to-understand way. This course would be even better if more interactive classroom activities are designed and more students can get involved.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Chris is an amazing professor and a great person to be teaching this class. He was always direct, honest, and sensitive to all students and all material.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: good
Learn about ethics, publishing, grant-writing, and academia at large. Yes, I would recommend it.
very good class, would recommend
I recommend it
Useful for research student
I will recommend it to other students.
This course provides important information in many aspects for almost every student. It is required, and indeed necessary for students.
This course provides a good overview of some of the ethical, interpersonal, and research quandaries that you may encounter- and how you can best respond to them- in the public health field.
